discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Cluster Class introduced from vSphere 8.0, https://tanzu.vmware.com/content/blog/clusterclass-deployments-tanzu-kubernetes-grid-2-0
class-based workload clusters can only be deployed on supervisor clusters on vSphere 8

comments.content:
seems to be right:
Starting in version 8.0 of vSphere, you can leverage the power of ClusterClass to use a predefined baseline configuration to create clusters with a consistent size and shape in Tanzu Kubernetes Grid Service Supervisor Clusters
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-Tanzu-Mission-Control/services/tanzumc-using/GUID-41DE8F22-56B8-4669-AF3F-E4B4372BDB9E.html

questions.question_text: Which version of VMware vSphere introduces the capability for provisioning a workload cluster using a cluster class (ClusterClass) from VMware Tanzu Mission Control?
Which two statements describe Kubernetes observability characteristics? (Choose two.)

choices.C: It observes the code of the applications running in Kubernetes environment
choices.E: Automatically heals Kubernetes workloads after an issue has been observed
choices.D: Collects real-time metrics from all layers of Kubernetes
choices.B: Provides visibility into Kubernetes clusters for troubleshooting and impact assessment
choices.A: It provides network insight and detailed Kubernetes network topology view

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AB
It also provides network insights, so the correct answers are A and B.

B. Provides visibility into Kubernetes clusters for troubleshooting and impact assessment
D. Collects real-time metrics from all layers of Kubernetes

A -> To provision vSphere Pods, or Tanzu Kubernetes clusters by using the Tanzu Kubernetes Grid Service, you connect to the Supervisor Cluster by using the vSphere Plugin for kubectl and authenticate with your vCenter Single Sign-On credentials

D -> To use kubectl and tmc (the Tanzu Mission Control CLI) with a provisioned cluster, download the generated configuration file and initialize the connection.

After you have attached or provisioned a new cluster using Tanzu Mission Control, you can connect to it with kubectl using the configuration file that Tanzu Mission Control generates for you.

choices.C: Download on the Supervisor Cluster Webpage
choices.E: Access from VMware Tanzu Mission Control
choices.A: Use the command kubectl vsphere login
choices.D: Access from vCenter Server Appliance Management Interface

questions.question_text: Which two are valid options for obtaining kubectl config file in Tanzu Kubernetes environment? (Choose two.)
What is the correct procedure to attach a management cluster using the Tanzu Mission Control web console?

choices.A: On the Clusters page, select the "Management Clusters" tab, Click "Register Management Cluster", and select the type of management cluster to register.
choices.D: On the Administration page, select the "Management Clusters" tab, Click "Register Management Cluster", and select the type of management cluster to register.
choices.C: On the Administration page, select "Attach Cluster" and then select the "Management Cluster" option, complete the form, and click the "Connect" button.
choices.B: On the Clusters page, select "Attach Cluster" and then select the "Management Cluster" option, complete the form, and click the "Connect" button.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
On the Administration page, select the "Management Clusters" tab....

Selected Answer: D
See Lukes link

Selected Answer: D
tmc cluster upgrade <clustername> [version] [flags]
